text:
CLINICAL HISTORY:  A ___ man with a history of metastatic renal cell
cancer with torso CT showing new lytic lesion at T2 with extension into the
spinal canal.  Evaluate for cord compression at T2 level.

TECHNIQUE:  A thoracic and lumbar spine MRIs obtained pre- and
post-intravenous administration of 10 cc of Gadavist contrast.

COMPARISON:  Compared to a lumbar spine MRI from ___ and a thoracic
spine MRI from ___.

FINDINGS:

THORACIC SPINE:  Compared to the thoracic spine MRI of ___, the
T2 pathologic compression fracture has progressed.  There is mild bony
retropulsion with suggestion of enhancing epidural disease at this level. 
There is no cord signal abnormality.

The T7 heterogeneously hyperintense lesion on the T2 and STIR images has also
increased in size.  There is no bony retropulsion at this level.  The
hypointense lesion at the inferior endplate of T11 vertebral body posteriorly
is stable in size when compared to the lumbar spine MRI from ___. 
The remainder of the thoracic vertebral bodies are unremarkable.

Compared to the ___, there is new anterior and posterior
enhancing epidural metastatic disease from the T10 through the L1 level. 
There is moderate canal stenosis at these levels.

LUMBAR SPINE:
The patient is status post laminectomies from L3 through S1.  There is high
signal within the vertebral bodies on T1 compatible with fatty bone marrow
replacement from prior radiation.  Again noted are multiple metastatic lesions
seen from T11 through the sacrum and iliac wings that are grossly stable from
___.  The conus ends at T12-L1 level.

There is stable appearance of the L2 vertebral body, which is largely replaced
by tumor and has mild vertebral body height loss.  There is moderate canal
stenosis due to small retropulsion of the metastatic lesion into the epidural
space.

There are stable multilevel degenerative disc disease, most notably at the
L3-L4 where there is severe spinal canal narrowing decompressed by posterior
laminectomy.  There is severe bilateral neural foraminal narrowing with
compression of the exiting L3 nerve roots.

IMPRESSION:  
Compared with the prior thoracic spine MRI of ___, there is
further collapse of the T2 pathologic fracture with likely epidural extension
of metastatic disease  .  Also, metastatic lesion within the T7 vertebral body
has increased in size.  There is new enhancing anterior and posterior epidural
metastatic disease from T10 through L1 levels.

There is stable extensive metastatic disease within the lumbar spine and
pelvis as described above.

HISTORY:  Palpitations.

COMPARISON:  ___.

FINDINGS:  The cardiac silhouette is enlarged and unchanged.  There is no
evidence of pneumothorax, consolidation, or pleural effusion.  Increased
interstitial markings are again noted.  The pulmonary vasculature is normal.
The osseous structures demonstrate degenerative changes of the spine.

IMPRESSION:  No evidence of CHF or pneumonia.

SUPINE AND UPRIGHT ABDOMEN, ___ AT 1408 HOURS.

HISTORY:  Reported no bowel movements x3 weeks.

COMPARISON:  CT of the abdomen and pelvis earlier same day.

FINDINGS:  A non-obstructive bowel gas pattern is noted.  There is gas within
the rectal vault.  No significant fecal loading is noted.  There is no free
air under the diaphragm.  A calcification is seen in the left upper quadrant. 
A phlebolith is noted in the left hemipelvis.

IMPRESSION:  Non-obstructive bowel gas pattern.  Despite the given history, no
significant fecal loading noted.

INDICATION:  Abdominal distention for three weeks, evaluate for obstruction.

COMPARISON:  AXR ___.

TECHNIQUE:  MDCT-acquired axial images from the lung bases to the pubic
symphysis were displayed with 5-mm slice thickness with 130 mL Optiray
intravenous contrast.  Coronal and sagittal reformats were displayed with 5-mm
slice thickness.

CT ABDOMEN:  Tiny bilateral pleural effusions and mild bibasilar atelectasis
are noted. There is no focal consolidation. There is no pericardial effusion
although the heart is slightly enlarged. 

Multiple hypodensities within the liver, some of which are too small to
characterize and others of which are cysts, the largest measuring 3.6 x 3.2 x
4.9 cm near the hepatic dome are seen. There are no definite liver lesions
suspicious for metastases on this single phase study. A splenic calcification
suggests exposure to prior granulomatous disease. The gallbladder, pancreas
and bilateral adrenal glands are normal. The kidneys enhance symmetrically and
excrete contrast promptly without hydronephrosis.  Multiple hypodensities are
seen in the kidneys bilaterally, some of which are too small to characterize
and others of which are cysts, the largest measuring 3.0 x 3.5 cm in the left
interpolar region. 

The small is normal in course and calibur without obstruction. No discrete
colon lesion is seen although eccentric wall thickening in the transverse
colon, just distal to the hepatic flexure (2:41, 601b: 17) raises the
possibility of colonic malignancy. There is mild colonic fecal loading without
obstruction. There is no free air. Large simple ascites with omental caking,
is worrisome for malignant ascites. Atherosclerotic calcifications are seen in
the normal caliber aorta.  The main portal vein, splenic vein, and SMV are
patent. No pathologically enlarged mesenteric or retroperitoneal lymph nodes
are present.

CT PELVIS:  The rectum and sigmoid colon are normal.  The uterus is grossly
normal with numerous collaterals and a distended left ovarian vein.  There is
no pelvic or inguinal lymphadenopathy. The ovaries appear normal with a focal
calcification in the right ovary. Pelvic ascites tracks from the abdomen.

BONE WINDOWS:  No lytic or sclerotic lesion suspicious for malignancy is seen.
Multilevel degenerative change is seen in the thoracic and lumbar spines with
endplate sclerosis and loss of disc space height with vacuum phenomenon.

IMPRESSION: Large ascites and omental caking/peritoneal implants raise concern
for malignany, possibly due to colonic primary given eccentric wall thickening
in the transverse colon. Correlate with colonoscopy. No obstruction.

Change in wet read discussed with Dr. ___ (medicine resident) by
phone at 5:42pm ___.

INDICATION:  An ___ female with ascites, weight loss, omental caking
on CT.

COMPARISON:  Abdomen and pelvis CT, ___.

FINDINGS:  On transabdominal imaging, there is a large amount of ascites seen
within the pelvis.  An endovaginal exam was attempted for better visualization
of the uterus and ovaries.  The uterus is identified and measures 4.0 x 1.5 x
2.3 cm.  Despite diligent effort, the ovaries could not be identified.  No
suspicious soft tissue mass is seen within the right or left adnexa.

IMPRESSION:  Very limited study.  The uterus appears normal.  The ovaries
could not be identified.  A large amount of ascites is seen in the pelvis.

INDICATION:  Evaluation of patient with new-onset ascites, for therapeutic and
diagnostic paracentesis.

COMPARISON:  CT abdomen and pelvis from ___.

PROCEDURE:  Initial four quadrant ultrasound demonstrates large amount of
intraabdominal free fluid consistent with ascites.  Following discussion of
the risks, benefits, and alternatives to procedure, written informed consent
was obtained.  The right lower quadrant was selected as large pocket of free
fluid.  A preprocedure timeout using three patient identifiers was performed. 
The skin was prepped and draped in usual sterile fashion.  Approximately 9 cc
of 1% of lidocaine were infiltrated into the skin and subcutaneous tissues for
local anesthesia.  A 5 ___ ___ catheter was then passed into the
peritoneum under direct ultrasound guidance.  The catheter was then attached
to individual suction bottles and 2.5 liters of clear yellow serous fluid were
drained.  Diagnostic samples were sent to the lab.  There were no immediate
complications.  The patient was transferred back to the floor for further
monitoring.  Dr. ___, the attending radiologist, was present
throughout the procedure.

IMPRESSION:  Technically successful diagnostic and therapeutic paracentesis
under direct ultrasound guidance with 2.5 liters of light yellow-stained
serous fluid removed.

INDICATION:  ___ woman with new onset ascites, constipation.  Negative
colonoscopy and omental caking on CT scan.

COMPARISON:  CT abdomen and pelvis, ___.

CT INTERVENTIONAL PROCEDURE:  The risks, benefits and alternatives of the
procedure were described to the patient in the presence of an interpreter. All
the patient's questions were answered and the patient provided written
informed consent.  A preprocedure timeout was performed using three patient
identifiers.  The patient was placed supine on the CT table and planning CT
was performed. This showed evidence of large volume ascites and omental
nodularity.  Suitable site for biopsy was chosen in superficial position to
the left of the midline just below the left abdominal wall.  The overlying
skin was prepped and draped in standard sterile fashion.   1% buffered
lidocaine was infiltrated into the skin and subcutaneous tissues for local
anesthesia.  Under CT fluoroscopic guidance, a 17-gauge introducer sheath was
passed into the soft tissue mass.  A total of three 18-gauge cores were
obtained and given to the cytopathologist, who was onsite during the procedure
to confirm adequacy of specimen.  Once adequacy was confirmed, the needle was
removed. The patient tolerated the procedure well without evidence of
immediate post-procedure complications.

MODERATE SEDATION:  Moderate sedation was provided by administering divided
doses of fentanyl and Versed throughout the total intraservice time of 25
minutes, during which time the patient's hemodynamic parameters were
continuously monitored.  A total of 50 mcg of fentanyl and 1 mg of Versed were
administered.  Dr. ___ attending physician, performed the procedure.

IMPRESSION:  Successful CT core biopsy of omental implant with no immediate
post-procedure complications.

INDICATION:  ___ female with peritoneal metastases and unknown primary
cancer with history of malignant ascites, now with recurrent abdominal
distention, here for ultrasound-guided diagnostic and therapeutic
paracentesis.

COMPARISON:  Ultrasound-guided diagnostic and therapeutic paracentesis last
performed on ___.

PROCEDURE:  Initial four-quadrant ultrasound demonstrates no appreciable free
fluid within the abdomen or pelvis.  There is a small amount of perisplenic
ascites; however, only gas-filled loops of bowel are seen filling the right
and left lower quadrant.  No ascites is identified.  The decision was made
with the attending radiologist, Dr. ___, to cancel the procedure.

IMPRESSION:  No ascites is seen.

INDICATION:  Evaluation of patient with tachycardia.

COMPARISON:  Chest radiograph from ___.

TECHNIQUE:  Single supine chest radiograph was obtained.

FINDINGS:  Mild bibasilar atelectasis.  Small bilateral pleural effusions are
noted.  Otherwise, the lungs are clear with no evidence of consolidation or
pneumothorax.  The cardiac silhouette appears enlarged but stable.  

IMPRESSION:  Bibasilar atelectasis and small bilateral pleural effusions. 
Stable cardiomegaly.

INDICATION:  Tachycardia, assess for pulmonary embolism.

TECHNIQUE:  MDCT-acquired axial images were obtained through the lungs prior
to and in arterial phase after administration of intravenous contrast. 
Coronal and sagittal reformations were prepared.

COMPARISONS:  Chest radiograph ___.

FINDINGS:  Thyroid gland is normal in appearance.  Mediastinum is unremarkable
with the exception of a small axial hiatal hernia.  Atherosclerotic
calcifications are noted in the aorta.  The aorta and major branches are
patent with normal three-vessel arch.  There is no axillary, hilar,
supraclavicular, or mediastinal adenopathy, though scattered non-enlarged
nodes are seen.  The heart and pericardium are unremarkable, with trace
pericardial effusion as on the prior abdominal CT.  Small bilateral simple
pleural effusions are slightly increased.    The lungs are otherwise clear
without focal opacity. There are pulmonary emboli involving the right middle
and lower lobar as well as left lower lobar pulmonary arteries.  The right
ventricle is not enlarged to suggest right heart strain.  

Though the study is not tailored for subdiaphragmatic evaluation, imaged upper
abdomen demonstrates cirrhotic liver with multiple hypodensities, better
characterized on previous CT of the abdomen and pelvis as well as moderate
volume ascites, similar to the prior study.

OSSEOUS STRUCTURES:  There is no lytic or sclerotic bony lesion concerning for
osseous malignant process.

IMPRESSION:  Pulmonary emboli involving the right middle and lower lobar as
well as left lower lobar pulmonary arteries without evidence of right heart
strain.  Small bilateral simple pleural effusions are slightly increased.

INDICATION:  ___ woman with gastric cancer and recurrent ascites. 
Request abdominal Pleurx catheter.

OPERATORS:  Dr. ___ and Dr. ___ performed the
procedure.

ANESTHESIA:  Moderate sedation was provided by administering divided doses of
fentanyl and Versed throughout the intraservice time of 34 minutes, during
which the patient's hemodynamic parameters were continuously monitored.

MEDICATIONS:  2 g of ceftriaxone and 5 mg of Lopressor was given during the
procedure.

PROCEDURE:  Written informed consent was obtained from the patient along with
an interpreter after explaining the risks, benefits, and alternatives to the
procedure.  The patient was brought into the angio suite and placed supine on
the table.  The right flank and left arm were prepped and draped in a sterile
fashion.

The patient did not have any venous access, so venous access was obtained on
the left arm through the brachial vein.

Now, the attention was shifted to the right flank.  A pocket of ascites was
identified by ultrasound and a micropuncture needle was placed in the ascitic
pocket and a guidewire was passed through the micropuncture needle, which was
then exchanged for a micropuncture sheath.  Then, attention was shifted to
performing a tunnel, which was made superiorly and medial to the entrance
site.  The track was anesthetized with lidocaine and epinephrine. A ___ was
given at the entrance of the tunnel and a tunneling device was used to tunnel
the Pleurx catheter through the abdomen ending at the entrance site. Then,
serial dilations were performed at the entrance site and a peel-away sheath
was introduced.  The Pleurx catheter was introduced through the peel-away
sheath and the placement was confirmed fluoroscopically.  Then, the venotomy
site was closed with ___ Vicryl sutures and the catheter was anchored using 0
silk sutures.  Then, sterile dressings were applied to the catheter.

The patient tolerated the procedure well.  She did not have any immediate
complications.

IMPRESSION:  Uncomplicated placement of a abdominal Pleurx catheter.

INDICATION:  Tachycardia.

___.

PORTABLE UPRIGHT AP VIEW OF THE CHEST:  Compared with the prior study, there
has been interval development of a moderate-to-large left pleural effusion,
and persistent small right pleural effusion.  Bibasilar airspace opacities are
present, most likely reflecting compressive atelectasis though infection
cannot be excluded.  There is mild pulmonary vascular engorgement.  Evaluation
of the cardiac silhouette size is difficult given the presence of the left
pleural effusion.  No pneumothorax is present.  There are no acute osseous
abnormalities.

IMPRESSION:  Interval development of moderate-to-large left pleural effusion
and persistent small right pleural effusion with bibasilar airspace opacities,
likely atelectasis though infection is not excluded.  Mild pulmonary vascular
congestion.

HISTORY:  ___ female with gastric cancer, dyspnea, tachycardia, chest
pain.

STUDY:  MDCT through the chest before and the administration of 130 ml of
Optiray intravenous contrast in the pulmonary arterial phase.  Multiplanar
reformatted images were also generated.  Subsequently, MDCT images were
generated through the abdomen and pelvis; multiplanar reformatted images were
generated.

COMPARISON:  chest CTA dated ___ and CT abdomen/pelvis from ___.

FINDINGS:

CHEST:  The visualized portion of the thyroid appears unremarkable.  There is
no axillary, hilar, or mediastinal lymphadenopathy.  The aorta is of normal
caliber along its course without evidence of dissection or intramural
hematoma.  The pulmonary arterial trunk is of normal caliber. There is no
change in the extent and distribution of pulmonary emboli within the branches
of the right middle lobe, right lower lobe basal segments, lingular branch,
and left lower lobe basal segments.  The heart shows no evidence of right
heart  strain.  There is trace pericardial thickening/effusion.  Moderate
simple layering pleural effusions are increased from prior, with associated
compressive lower lobe atelectasis. There is fluid distension of the esophagus
which can predispose patient to aspiration. There is likely a component of
aspiration resulting in the basilar consolidations. 

ABDOMEN:  Several liver hypodense lesions appear stable and are most
compatible with cysts. The gallbladder is normal. The spleen contains a coarse
calcification and appears stable.  The pancreas is atrophic.  The adrenal
glands are normal. The kidneys enhance normally. There are multiple bilateral
renal cysts, though several atre too small to fully characterize.  

A peritoneal drain enters the right abdominal wall and the tip resides in the
right mid-abdomen. There is loculation of ascitic fluid with thickening and
hyperenhancement of the surrounding peritoneum. This appearance is very
concerning for peritonitis. There are locules of gas within the peritoneum
which could be secondary to the indwelling peritoneal drain. The possibility
of gas formining organism is difficult to exclude. There is no evidence of
bowel perforation. There is, however, small bowel submucosal edema involving
the bowel which is surrounding by the loculated ascites. Given the stated
concern for infected fluid, the bowel wall thickening could be reactive. There
is no bowel onstruction. 

There is again noted to be peritoneal carcinomatosis evidenced by omental
implants. There is likely serosal disease of bowel.  A 3.0 x 1.3 cm (3b;119)
soft tissue mass is seen in the left anterior abdominal wall, concerning for
metastatic seeding of a prior paracentesis tract.

The aortal is normal in course and caliber with scattered atherosclerotic
calcification. The IVC is flattened and not visualized just inferior to the
renal veins. There may be thrombus within a left iliac vein on series 3b,
image 127. 

PELVIS:  Bladder appears unremarkable.  The uterus demonstrates calcification
within the myometrium, likely vascular.  The rectum appears unremarkable. 
There is free fluid contiguous with the ascites in the abdomen.  No
lymphadenopathy is seen. 

BONES:  No aggressive-appearing lytic or sclerotic lesions are seen. Diffuse
body wall edema noted. 

IMPRESSION:
1.  Interval development of hyperenhancement and thickening of the peritoneum
with large volume loculated ascites raises concern for peritonitis. Presence
of gas within peritoneum could be due to indwelling catheter though gas
forming organism cannot be excluded. This finding was discussed with ___
___ at 19:24 on ___ by ___ over the phone.
2.  Small bowel wall thickening likely reactive given the concern for infected
peritoneal fluid. No bowel obstruction. 
3.  Unchanged bilateral pulmonary emboli.
4.  Increased bilateral pleural effusions with associated lower lobe
consolidation, likely reflects atelectasis and aspiration.
5.  Extensive peritoneal carcinomatosis.

INDICATION:  Chest pain.

COMPARISON:  None.

TECHNIQUE:  Upright AP and lateral views of the chest.

FINDINGS:  The heart size is mildly enlarged.  The aorta is slightly tortuous
and calcified.  There is no pulmonary vascular congestion.  Hilar contours are
unremarkable.  There is minimal streaky atelectasis in the lung bases.  No
focal consolidation, pleural effusion or pneumothorax is seen.  Degenerative
changes are noted involving both acromioclavicular and glenohumeral joints,
which are moderate in degree.  Mild-to-moderate multilevel degenerative
changes are also seen within the thoracic spine.

IMPRESSION:  Mild bibasilar atelectasis.  No acute cardiopulmonary abnormality
otherwise demonstrated.

HISTORY:  ___ man with new pacemaker.

COMPARISON:   ___.

FINDINGS:

New left chest subclavian atrial ventricular defibrillator leads follow their
expected courses.  There is no pneumothorax, pleural effusion or mediastinal
widening.  Lungs are clear.  Moderate to severe cardiomegaly is unchanged. 
There is no pulmonary edema or pulmonary vascular congestion.

IMPRESSION:

Normal post insertion appearance, atrioventricular pacemaker lead.  No
complications.

HISTORY:  ___ woman status post fall.  Assess for acute intracranial
process.

COMPARISON:  None.

TECHNIQUE:  Non-contrast MDCT images were acquired through the brain. 
Multiplanar reformatted images were obtained for evaluation.

FINDINGS:  There is no acute intracranial hemorrhage, edema, mass effect or
major vascular territorial infarct.  The mildly prominent ventricles and sulci
are compatible with age-related global atrophy.  There is no shift of normally
midline structures.  The gray-white matter differentiation is well preserved. 
There is no acute fracture.  Scattered mild ethmoidal and right maxillary
sinus opacity noted.  The remaining visualized paranasal sinuses and mastoid
air cells are clear.  There are scattered vascular calcifications.

IMPRESSION:  No acute intracranial process.

CERVICAL SPINE

HISTORY:  Evaluate for C-spine injury after fall.

AP and lateral views.  Positioning is suboptimal.  There is minimal anterior
loss of height of the C5 vertebral body.  There are small marginal osteophytes
most pronounced anteriorly at C5, C6 and C7.  There is moderate narrowing of
the C5-6 and C6-7 disc spaces.  Posterior elements appear intact in two
projections.  The odontoid process appears intact.  Alignment is normal. 
Precervical soft tissues are unremarkable.

IMPRESSION:  Minimal loss of height of the C5 vertebral body which is probably
old.  Mild degenerative arthritic change, most pronounced in the lower
cervical spine.  Disc space narrowing C5-6 and C6-7, most likely chronic as
well.
